title: NASA Picks Three Contractors to Lead Lunar Lander Teams
summary: NASA chief says nearly $1 billion in awards hedges bets on different solutions to offer greater likelihood of success by 2024.

title: J.Crew Prepares to File for Bankruptcy
summary: Apparel chain was struggling before coronavirus pandemic forced retailers to close stores. J.Crew Group Inc., the preppy retailer that recently fell on hard times, is preparing to file for bankruptcy protection, one of several high-profile U.S. chains that are on the verge of unraveling during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: The Main Street Fakeout
summary: The Fed's terms suggest it really doesn't want to lend to these companies.. The Federal Reserve on Thursday rolled out revised terms for its Main Street Lending Program, and we wonder why it bothered. The details suggest the Fed and Treasury would rather not have anyone use the facility.

title: Democratic Governors Reopen
summary: Trying to salvage an economy shouldn't be a partisan issue.. Liberals and their media friends assert that GOP governors will have blood on their hands if they ease their coronavirus economic shutdowns. Don't look now, but even a couple of Democratic governors are making plans to reopen.

title: Apple Sales Edge Higher, Showing Resilience in Pandemic
summary: The iPhone maker had warned in February that demand for its products was weakening in China. Apple Inc. reported a slight uptick in revenue for its latest quarter even as the coronavirus shut down factories and dented sales in China, as the tech giant's growing services business offset declining iPhone sales.

title: Mindless in Seattle
summary: As unemployment soars, the City Council wants to tax job creation.. The economy is on life support, but that isn't stopping the Seattle City Council from trying to soak employers with a new tax on hiring. The wizards seem not to have heard that when you tax something you get less of it.

title: The Iron Lady and the Coronavirus Age
summary: Like Thatcher, we'll need to achieve much out of the ordinary. Love of country is the place to start.. I've been trying to get a sense of the economic effects of the 1918 flu pandemic, which killed an estimated 675,000 Americans. Government record-keeping in those days wasn't what it is now; there's not much data. You see references in academic papers to factories closed, businesses shuttered. You see newspaper pictures of people in masks and clippings about people dying in hallways. Yet what followed was the Roaring '20s-expansive, even ecstatic economic growth.

title: Limit Governors' Emergency Powers
summary: Residents and business owners want lockdown relief, but few legislatures have any way to intervene.. As governors across the country destroy their states' economies in the name of public health, there is shockingly little oversight of their actions.

title: An Allied Plan to Depend Less on China
summary: The U.S., Australia, Japan and India already have a forum for coordination.. The Covid-19 pandemic is prompting reconsideration of issues that were thought to be settled. One is the wisdom of China as a hub in vital supply chains, a reality driven by cost considerations and the belief that integrating China into the global economy would moderate Beijing's behavior. Unfortunately, China hasn't moderated. Beijing has been an unreliable supplier that pressures trading partners.

title: India May Have to Lift Its Coronavirus Lockdown
summary: The infection rate, while low, continues to rise. But unemployment is a luxury in such a poor country.. As Covid-19 rages around the world, governments are wrestling with the trade-off between lives and livelihoods. In few places is the dilemma more difficult than in India. Infections haven't spiked dramatically, but they show no sign of abating either. At the same time, compared with rich countries, India has an even harder time affording the luxury of keeping its economy in suspended animation.

title: 'The Golden Flea' Review: Everything Must Go
summary: A lyrical memoir of the old Chelsea flea market, a grimy pocket of New York commerce that was also, to believers, the 'avatar of the unknown.'. Of the countless New York structures demolished over the years, a parking garage may seem a strange one to mourn, but Michael Rips mourns one with infectious poignancy in his quirky, disarming, sometimes strained yet altogether beautiful memoir "The Golden Flea."

title: The FBI's Flynn Outrage
summary: New documents shock the conscience and demonstrate the need for accountability.. The newest Federal Bureau of Investigation documents in the case of former White House national security adviser Mike Flynn are stunning in themselves. But the totality of Mr. Flynn's treatment shocks the conscience.

title: Coronavirus and 'Vindication of God'
summary: The pandemic raises the old question of theodicy, the core dilemma of faith.. The great Lisbon earthquake on Nov. 1, 1755, All Saint's Day, killed perhaps 50,000. No one is certain of the death toll. The tsunami that followed the quake killed still more, and so did the fire that started when the heaving earth capsized votive candles. Most important, these events altered the Western mind.

title: Revlon Overcomes Holdout Creditors on $65 Million Rescue Loan
summary: Cosmetics company borrows money to weather economic slowdown, overcoming opposition from some lenders. Revlon Inc. overcame objections from a group of lenders to borrow $65 million in rescue financing, paving the way for a broader debt restructuring to help it weather the economic shutdown.

title: Tech Stocks Nearly Push Nasdaq Out of Red
summary: Investors are betting that the companies that drove much of the recent decadelong bull rally will lead the recovery from the coronavirus market crash. The Nasdaq Composite stock index is on the cusp of recouping all its losses for the year.

title: Anti-Money-Laundering Watchdog Urges U.A.E. to Strengthen Enforcement
summary: Investigating and prosecuting gold smugglers was one of several recommendations from the Financial Action Task Force. The United Arab Emirates has taken steps to combat money laundering in recent years but should more aggressively investigate and prosecute financial crimes, including the smuggling of gold and precious stones across its borders, a global watchdog said.

title: American Posts Big Loss as Air Travel Collapsed
summary: Airline is streamlining its fleet, retiring some jets early to cut costs. The world's largest airline said it is going to have to get smaller.

title: Ryder System Cuts Costs With Zero-Based Budgeting Amid Business Slowdown
summary: The truck leasing and fleet management company slashed its travel budget and furloughed back-office workers. Ryder System Inc.'s use of zero-based budgeting to manage its monthly spending has helped it navigate the economic downturn caused by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Intelligence Agencies Confirm Wuhan Virus Investigation
summary: No concrete evidence has emerged to support the theory; China has repeatedly denied it. WASHINGTON-The U.S. intelligence community publicly confirmed it is trying to determine whether the coronavirus may have escaped from a laboratory in Wuhan, the city where the pandemic began.

title: MGM Resorts CEO: Las Vegas Reopening Will Start With Two or Three Casinos
summary: MGM Resorts' net revenue decreased 29% in the three months ended March 31. Once the Las Vegas Strip is cleared to reopen, MGM Resorts International will open two or three of its casinos, including the flagship Bellagio, as part of a gradual relaunch, acting Chief Executive Bill Hornbuckle told Wall Street analysts.

title: Texas Shale Driller Concho Takes $12.6 Billion Charge, Citing Coronavirus Impacts
summary: The write-down, which comes two years after Concho bought a rival for $9.5 billion, is among the largest by an oil and gas producer in recent years. Texas shale driller Concho Resources Inc. reported a net quarterly loss of $9.3 billion Thursday and wrote down the value of its oil and gas assets by $12.6 billion, a sign of the severe stress U.S. oil and gas companies are feeling as demand for their products erodes.

title: Amazon's Sales Jump as Coronavirus Prompts Surge in Online Shopping
summary: Sharp increase in orders, though, taxes fulfillment centers; profit misses expectations. Amazon.com Inc. reported soaring quarterly sales as homebound customers flooded it with online shopping orders, capping a string of earnings reports from big tech companies that show how the coronavirus pandemic has fueled demand for their products and services.

title: Working From Home for the Long Haul? Get the Ergonomics Right
summary: Ten simple hacks for improving your work setup at home. When the coronavirus first swept through the U.S., millions of workers got a laptop and were told to hunker down at home. Now, for many, pain and eyestrain are setting in.

title: New York Seeks Solutions for Covid-19 Dead After Bodies Found in Brooklyn
summary: Police discovered dozens of corpses in vehicles parked on a busy street. New York politicians are seeking answers on how to handle the growing number of corpses left by the coronavirus pandemic, after dozens of bodies were discovered decomposing in rental trucks outside a Brooklyn funeral home.

title: You've Got Mail. The Old-Fashioned Kind.
summary: Next in Journal Reports: Coronavirus. Since getting furloughed from her audiology job nearly two months ago, Miranda Flanagan of Weymouth, Mass., has had a lot of free time on her hands. Now she's putting those hands to good use, writing letters to friends near and far.

title: Apple Survives While Amazon Thrives
summary: Both exceeded Wall Street's sales forecasts, but Amazon is better-suited to the pandemic's aftermath. Apple Inc. and Amazon.com will get through the coronavirus pandemic and its aftermath just fine. But the iPhone giant has a tougher path ahead.

title: Gilead to Expand Manufacturing of Covid-19 Drug Remdesivir
summary: Drug meant to treat patients with serious cases of the illness caused by coronavirus. Gilead Sciences Inc. said it has moved to expand manufacturing of remdesivir, a drug meant to treat patients with serious cases of Covid-19.

title: AmEx Mistakenly Issued Card to German Under Sanctions
summary: Approval of a prepaid card was found to be due to technical and human errors, and AmEx wasn't fined. An American Express Co. subsidiary mistakenly issued a prepaid card to a German engineer with alleged ties to a black market in nuclear-weapons technology, the Treasury said Thursday.

title: Federal Reserve Expands Business Lending Program
summary: Eligibility and loan terms have been loosened on the $600 billion effort targeting midsize businesses hit by the coronavirus pandemic. The Federal Reserve will expand loan offerings and qualification rules for its forthcoming $600 billion lending effort designed to reach small and midsize businesses hit by the coronavirus pandemic, the central bank said Thursday.

title: In This Crisis, There's a Right Way to Give People Financial Gifts-and a Wrong Way
summary: Recipients can feel embarrassment and shame, unless you're smart about it. With the pandemic forcing millions of Americans into financial distress, it is only natural to want to lend friends and family a hand.

title: Why Virus Hit Michigan's Economy Harder, Longer
summary: State's reliance on manufacturing and jump in Covid-19 cases are compounding impact of pandemic. DETROIT-The growing economic crisis triggered by the pandemic is expected to last longer and hit harder in Michigan than in most places, as the state deals with the fallout of a severe coronavirus outbreak and ongoing dependence on manufacturing.

title: AT&T's WarnerMedia Absorbs Xandr Ad Tech Unit
summary: The combination of the two units has long been expected by current and former WarnerMedia and Xandr executives. AT&T Inc. is combining its WarnerMedia and Xandr business units-which has long been expected by company insiders-in an effort to have a single advertising sales and technology offering across the company.

title: Florida Cancer Center to Pay $100 Million Antitrust Penalty
summary: Under agreement with Justice Department, treatment center admits to nearly two-decade conspiracy to limit patients' options. WASHINGTON-A Florida cancer-treatment center admitted to engaging in a nearly two-decade conspiracy to limit competition for oncology treatments and will pay $100 million in criminal penalties, the Justice Department said Thursday, the first charges in a continuing probe of the industry.

title: Democrats Urge Joe Biden to Address Sexual Assault Allegation
summary: Prominent Democrats have defended Mr. Biden, whose campaign has denied the claim, but others say it could alienate voters. Former Vice President Joe Biden, under increasing pressure from some Democrats to respond to a sexual assault allegation made against him by a former Senate aide, is expected to face public questions on the issue for the first time Friday.

title: Comcast's Results Suffer as Coronavirus Hits Theme Parks, Movie Business
summary: Cable giant posts stable revenue thanks to strong broadband growth; pay-TV exodus continues. Comcast Corp. signed up more broadband customers last quarter than any time in 12 years, but that growth was more than offset by the coronavirus pandemic's impact on vast portions of its business, from movie production to theme parks.

title: Sherrod Brown: The Generation of Progressive Change
summary: Today's graduates have a rare chance to create a more just, fair and diverse America than we had before the virus. Your grandparents may brag to you about the good old days, and your parents may tell you that your generation is apathetic and self-centered. But I've seen something different. You are the most activist generation in decades.

title: This Isn't the Time for More Immigrants
summary: With all the other problems Covid-19 has created, allowing immigration to continue is just exacerbating the unemployment debacle.. Regarding your editorial "Trump's Immigration Distraction" (April 22): In the past month or so unemployment has risen from just over 3% to about 20%. Nearly 26 million Americans are either out of a job or working reduced hours.

title: The Really Small Business Administration
summary: Lumping 500-person companies and five-person gift shops together guaranteed that behemoths would trample the Main Street shops on their way to the front of the assistance line.. The overly broad definition of small businesses is responsible for publicly traded companies receiving Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) funds intended to help Main Street small businesses ("U.S. Urges Public Companies To Repay SBA Loans," Page One, April 24).

title: Coronavirus Is Accelerating Broadband Growth
summary: We will close rural broadband gaps faster, and more cost-effectively, if we let every provider-and every competing technology-participate in solving the problem.. Regarding "Broadband Changes Gain New Support" (The Coronavirus Pandemic, April 22): We will close rural broadband gaps faster, and more cost-effectively, if we let every provider-and every competing technology-participate in solving the problem. We also need to address the lack of computer hardware and digital literacy challenges that contribute to low adoption rates.

title: Some Do Well From Our 8-Track Government
summary: I watched my wife work for a county government on a mainframe that made my system look like it came from the future. She confessed that the software provider was a big contributor to the past supervisor.. Regarding Andy Kessler's "Upgrade Our 8-Track Government" (Inside View, April 20): I have watched my computer-science-major son advance in certifications, job positions and salaries since his graduation. He's fearless when it comes to learning new skills. By contrast, I just retired after 21 years in the private sector as a Cobol programmer. When I suggested to my colleagues some of the newer technologies that my son was learning, they were quickly discarded because the current managers either didn't know about them or were afraid of losing their jobs to a new system. This was all put into perspective as I watched my wife work for a county government on a mainframe that made my system look like it came from the future. She confessed that the software provider was a big contributor to the past supervisor.

title: U.S. Charges Honduran President's Police Ally in Drug Ring
summary: Former national police chief Juan Carlos Bonilla Valladares oversaw drug trafficking and violence, prosecutors allege. Manhattan federal prosecutors have charged the former chief of the Honduran National Police in a cocaine-trafficking conspiracy case, part of a sweeping investigation into drug-world corruption in Honduras that also implicates the country's president.

title: Nascar Makes Move, Announces May 17 Return From Coronavirus
summary: The race at Darlington Raceway in South Carolina will include no fans and social distancing. Nascar took the lead among major American sports in the quest to return from the coronavirus pandemic shutdown, announcing Thursday afternoon it will return to live racing May 17 at Darlington Raceway in Darlington, S.C.

title: 'Gold Digger' Review: A Love Story of the Ages
summary: When a romance blossoms between a 60-year-old woman and a man many years her junior, suspicions take root.. Would anyone have troubled to make a television series about an all-consuming love affair between a 60-year-old woman and a man roughly 30 years younger if the genders were reversed? Not likely is the answer, as the creators of the knowing, polished and gloriously spirited "Gold Digger" (begins Monday, Acorn TV) seem to have grasped. That's soon evident in the tale of Julia (Julia Ormond), newly divorced mother of three, who takes up with Benjamin (a stellar Ben Barnes), a man about half her age whom she's met outside of the British Museum. He's charmed by all that she can tell him about the obscure statue missing from the exhibition, and the way she tells it, and also by something else having nothing to do with art history-the thing about her that caused him to begin chatting her up in the first place that will resonate, as a question, to the end of this story.

title: Lenders to Acquire Dura Automotive for $55 Million
summary: In 2018, suitors offered $400 million or more for Dura, a supplier to Ford, Honda, BMW. Dura Automotive Systems LLC, a parts maker that drew buyout offers of more than $400 million in late 2018, is being taken over by the company's top lenders in bankruptcy for $55 million.

title: 'The Queen at War' Review: A Monarch Reflects the People
summary: PBS's documentary looks at Queen Elizabeth II's experiences during World War II that forever bound her to her subjects.. A new documentary on Queen Elizabeth II may, these days, raise expectations of facts already well known, of pictures seen many times before. It takes scarcely a few minutes' viewing to recognize that nothing of the kind feels true of "The Queen at War" (Tuesday, 8 p.m., PBS), an hour so evocative of the British during the Blitz, so rich in footage of Elizabeth's parents, the king and queen, standing in the rubble with bombed-out Londoners, that it seems, however often one has caught sight of them, that these scenes are all new, the crowds in them never seen before. What the film's treasury of footage offers is the chance to see in voluminous detail the close-up shots that capture the impact on the residents of London, filled with joy, and no little astonishment, at finding the royal couple standing among them, close to them.

title: Flynn Lawyers Say Documents Show FBI Tried to Set Him Up
summary: Trump's former national security adviser pleaded guilty but is now seeking to have his criminal case dismissed. A federal judge on Wednesday unsealed new documents in former national security adviser Mike Flynn's criminal case that his lawyers say are evidence the government tried to set him up in a 2017 interview that led to his departure from the Trump administration and subsequent indictment on a charge of lying.

title: Whirlpool Expects Revenue Decline
summary: Appliance maker seeks to trim $500 million in expenses through labor cuts and other measures. Whirlpool Corp. said it expects a double-digit decline in revenue this year as consumers put off buying some appliances because of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: With Students at Home, Mom and Dad Become Unfortunate Classmates
summary: Parents are getting new insights into their children's schooling during the lockdown-making life trickier for educators and families alike. There is a new child in class, a schoolmate who tends to lurk in the background, whisper while others are talking and dissect the teacher's skills. The student goes by the name "grown-up."

title: A Portrait of One Family in Coronavirus Lockdown
summary: Next in Journal Reports: Coronavirus. One recent spring evening, the Williams family gathered for Thanksgiving dinner.

title: New York to Hire 'Army of Tracers' to Combat Coronavirus
summary: Gov. Andrew Cuomo says state needs at least 30 tracers for every 100,000 people to follow path of those infected. New York will hire up to 17,000 contact tracers as part of a statewide effort to combat the novel coronavirus pandemic by tracking down people who have gone near those infected by Covid-19.

title: Israel's Largest Bank Pays $874 Million in U.S. Tax Evasion Case
summary: New York prosecutors say Bank Hapoalim hid more than $7.6 billion in Swiss and Israeli bank accounts. Israel's largest bank admitted to conspiring with U.S. customers and others to hide more than $7.6 billion in secret Swiss and Israeli bank accounts and, together with a Swiss subsidiary, will pay $874 million to resolve a sprawling U.S. tax-evasion investigation.

title: Coronavirus Closes a New York Drinking Institution. Will Others Follow?
summary: Pegu Club helped pioneer the craft-cocktail scene; its closure could be a sign of trouble for its peers. In what some are calling a sign of troubles to come for New York City's bar industry, Pegu Club, a pioneering drinking establishment that helped jump-start the craft-cocktail movement more than a decade ago, said Thursday it was shutting its doors for good.

title: Visa Posts Higher Quarterly Profit, Beating Projections
summary: Coronavirus hits card company's results, but profit and revenue still rise. The coronavirus pandemic hit Visa Inc.'s business in the March quarter, driving a 2% quarterly decline in the more profitable cross-border transactions, though the company posted higher quarterly profit.

title: Stocks Drop but Hold On to Big April Gains
summary: The Dow industrials finish April up 11%, their largest one-month percentage gain since 1987. U.S. stocks finished their best month in decades on a downbeat note Thursday after data on spending and unemployment offered new evidence of the coronavirus pandemic's reach.

title: Record Contraction in the Eurozone Bodes Ill for Quick Global Rebound
summary: Divergence between the Europe's north and south signals what could be longer-term stresses. The public-health crisis sparked by the new coronavirus ricocheted through Europe's economy in the first quarter, causing a record decline that was more severe even than in the U.S., an ominous sign for the global economy.

title: New York MTA Delays $1 Billion Bond Sale as It Scrambles for Funds
summary: Deal postponed until next week as state announces cuts in aid to authority. New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority postponed a roughly $1 billion bond sale this week as it grapples with a drastic reduction in ridership and cuts in state aid, highlighting how the global pandemic is upending the finances of mainstays in the normally staid municipal debt market.

title: Bestselling Books Week Ended April 25
summary: With data from NPD BookScan.

title: NYC Subways Won't Run 24 Hours a Day During Pandemic
summary: MTA to shut system down from 1 a.m to 5 a.m. to allow for deep cleaning. The New York City subway system will stop running 24 hours a day, an unprecedented move meant to help disinfect trains and stations and eject homeless people amid hygiene fears during the new coronavirus pandemic.

title: Pantry Loading Boosts Sales at Kraft Heinz, Kellogg
summary: Pressed by the pandemic, big food makers are also incurring higher costs to adjust supply chains. Kraft Heinz Co. and Kellogg Co. said the coronavirus pandemic has driven up demand for their packaged foods, giving them a chance to win back customers who stopped eating their cheese and cereal products long ago.

title: For Food Giants, This Crisis Is an Opportunity
summary: A temporary lift from an embrace of familiar brands should be an opportunity for packaged food companies to innovate.

title: New York Area Dental Offices Hit Hard by Coronavirus Pandemic
summary: Health-care and social-assistance industry is third-hardest hit, after hospitality and retail; 'Dental care is essential'. Staten Island dentist Craig Ratner knows his line of work puts him at risk of contracting the new coronavirus, but after six weeks of telling patients with broken crowns and chipped teeth that he can't see them, he wants to get back to work.

title: 'Deerskin': The Jacket Makes the Man
summary: A sartorial obsession hangs at the center of Quentin Dupieux's absurdist fable.. 'Deerskin" stars Jean Dujardin as a lost soul obsessed with a secondhand deerskin jacket. Mr. Dujardin won a best actor Oscar in 2012 for his buoyantly funny performance in "The Artist" as George Valentin, a silent-film star on the way down. Here he's Georges with an "s" but without the buoyancy or the fun, a man descending into murderous delusion. Quentin Dupieux's glum absurdist fable gives absurdism a bad name. It's a facile notion inflated to feature proportions-just barely, since the running time is only 77 minutes. Yet the film, in French, is interesting for the way it's being distributed at a time when theaters are shut-more about that later-and for what it says about deluded filmmakers.

title: Modell's Gets Further Pause on Liquidation, Angering Landlords
summary: Judge overseeing bankruptcy orders mediation between retailer and its landlords. A bankruptcy judge extended the suspension of Modell's Sporting Goods Inc.'s bankruptcy case until the end of May, allowing the retailer to stop paying rent as it waits for New York and neighboring states to lift restrictions on most shopping.

title: 'The Infiltrators': An Inside Job
summary: This docudrama tells the story of two young undocumented immigrant activists who get themselves detained to shed light on the conditions in ICE facilities.. It's hard to make an independent feature. Sometimes it's harder still to find a distribution company that will get the film into theaters for people to see. Now that theaters are closed many films are forced to wait for an opening date that depends on a larger opening date throughout the country. Others are seeking an audience in the here and now via streaming, even at the risk of getting lost in what's become a torrent. That's the path taken by "The Infiltrators." After a ritual journey on the festival circuit it was set to open theatrically in early April. Instead, the film, directed by Alex Rivera and Cristina Ibarra, is now part of the Virtual Cinema initiative that I've written about elsewhere this week (theinfiltrators.oscilloscope.net). I'm glad it is, and take it as a hopeful sign of growing diversity in the digital domain. For all its imperfections, this docudrama with an agitprop heart finds a surprising way into the subject of undocumented immigrants languishing in detention centers.

title: One Dead, Five Missing After Canadian Helicopter on NATO Mission Crashes Off Greece
summary: Aircraft part of military group patrolling eastern Mediterranean, Black Sea. One member of Canada's navy is dead and five other service members are missing after a helicopter that was on a North Atlantic Treaty Organization training mission crashed off the coast of Greece.

title: Fashion Mogul Peter Nygard Business Properties to Be Sold
summary: Nine Nygard companies filed for bankruptcy in the U.S. and Canada after sex-trafficking allegations against the mogul. A Canadian judge has given the green light to an accounting firm to sell and liquidate part of the business empire founded by fashion mogul Peter Nygard.

title: Russian Prime Minister Tests Positive for Coronavirus
summary: Putin appoints acting head of government to replace Mikhail Mishustin; country registers highest daily number of confirmed cases. MOSCOW-Russian Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin said he tested positive for the new coronavirus and is temporarily suspending duties in office, becoming the most recent head of government to contract the disease.

title: Claire Messud: A Moment for Inward Pilgrimages
summary: Today's students have had little space for the immaterial pleasures that make life worthwhile.. For the Class of 2020, as for all who aren't first responders or essential workers, your current duties lie, confusingly, in the negative: no gathering, no dancing or embracing, no jubilant parties. The defining rituals of the season have been suspended: proms, commencements, beach trips, parties and postgraduation travel. Instead, spring unfolds without us. In my backyard, rabbits gambol, squirrels leap and the birds sing with a new exuberance now that there's no traffic noise from the nearby highway. The world hasn't stopped, but our human social lives are in abeyance. How then to mark your graduation?

title: 'The Diary of Anne Frank' Review: Isolation as a Matter of Life and Death
summary: An ambitious Zoom-based performance of the stage version of the historic journal is an inspired, moving use of the software.. Zoom and other videoconferencing tools that allow the participants in a discussion to see and hear one another simultaneously on a computer screen are now being taken up by performing artists of all kinds who seek to circumvent the problem of social distancing and create electronically reconstituted "ensembles." Edward Rothstein wrote a piece for the Journal earlier this week that discussed how classical musicians are using Zoom and similar technologies to perform choral and orchestral works. If anything, theater artists are embracing such tools in even larger numbers, webcasting everything from newly commissioned two-person plays to large-scale performances like "Take Me to the World," the all-star celebration of Stephen Sondheim's 90th birthday that aired on Sunday.

title: Playing Dress-Up: More Vital Than Ever for Children Now
summary: In a parenting landscape where families are constantly at home, spacesuits and butterfly wings provide much-needed escapism. Here, some costume ideas.. A FEW WEEKS ago 2-year-old Claire put a bucket on her head and declared she was going to work. This is not an unusual occurrence in the young Bostonian's home, where she lives with her parents, Ryan Levasseur and Jeff Garber. Sometimes, she'll pair her pail with a tutu before clocking in at the imaginary office. In more adventurous moods, she'll transform it into an explorer's pith helmet.

title: Oil Rises on Hopes for Demand Recovery
summary: Gains come with some states in the U.S. easing lockdown measures. Oil prices advanced in volatile trading on Thursday, lifted by hopes for a rise in fuel consumption as lockdown measures to stop the coronavirus are rolled back.

title: U.K.'s Virus Death Toll Draws Scrutiny
summary: Critics link the high death count to a government delay in imposing a lockdown until March 23. LONDON-The U.K.'s official death count from the new coronavirus is rapidly rising toward that of Italy, Europe's worst-hit country so far, intensifying the scrutiny of the government's efforts to tackle the disease.

title: China Takes Harder Line on Hong Kong Amid Coronavirus Protest Lull
summary: Tensions are expected to rise as pro-democracy demonstrators plan to return to the streets after a lengthy absence amid the pandemic. HONG KONG-Tensions are set to rise as pro-democracy protesters attempt to return to the streets after a lengthy lull amid the coronavirus pandemic, which authorities here and in Beijing have used to push hard against the opposition movement.

title: FBI Director Previously Represented Facebook in Encryption Fight
summary: Wray has been pushing tech companies to give law-enforcement officials access to encrypted messages;. FBI Director Christopher Wray, who has been pushing tech companies to give law-enforcement authorities access to encrypted messages, once advocated the opposite view when representing Facebook Inc.'s WhatsApp in a legal case involving the messaging service's use of such technology, according to a new court filing.

title: Inside the Largest Coronavirus Outbreak in Immigration Detention
summary: Otay Mesa in California has more than 100 people who have tested positive for Covid-19; migrants complain they aren't being kept safe, contradicting official statements. As coronavirus infections surge in the nation's immigration jails, the number is highest at a low-slung lockup surrounded by barbed wire sitting just a few miles from the Mexican border in California.

title: Rod Dreher: Courage in the Darkness
summary: Ordinary people who faced down communism offer inspiration for dealing with our own challenges.. A young man once confided to a religious elder his anxiety over the hard times in which he was living. This is natural, said the elder, but such things are beyond our control: "All we have to decide is what to do with the time that is given us."

title: How Readers Say They Reacted to the Market Selloff
summary: We asked people to tell us their stories. Most remain optimistic, despite the coronavirus-racked markets.. "I haven't viewed this crisis as reason to divest, as unnerving as that is at times without any earned income coming in the door. My fundamental belief: In six months, or a year or two years, all of this will be in our rearview window. And the payoff after the crisis will be worth materially more than our current, temporary losses-if we don't panic."

title: A Private Beachfront Estate in the Bahamas Asks $45 Million
summary: If the roughly 3.5-acre property in Lyford Cay fetches that price, it would be one of the priciest homes ever sold in the country. A beachfront Bahamas estate asking $45 million would be one of the most expensive homes ever sold in the country if it fetches that price.

title: Top Colleges in the West for Student Engagement
summary: USC and Brigham Young tie atop this list from the WSJ/THE College Rankings. The top two colleges in the West for student engagement are tied with several schools from other regions for No. 4 nationwide in this component of the Wall Street Journal/Times Higher Education College Rankings.

title: Lawmakers Weigh Relief for U.S. Homeowners Facing Balloon Payments
summary: Some homeowners are being told they must make lump-sum payments at the end of their forbearance period. WASHINGTON-Lawmakers are considering ways to provide more relief for millions of homeowners who have taken advantage of a government offer to suspend mortgage payments amid the coronavirus pandemic.

title: A Bahamas Estate With Style
summary: The owner hired decorating legend Sister Parish to do the interiors.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Diamond Elite Members, Wait Here for Your Own Safety
summary: United Airlines is upending one of the key perks elite fliers enjoy, as the back of the plane boards first. Travelers flying on their own dime without elite status are familiar with the humiliation.

title: Coronavirus Prompts Record Drop in Consumer Spending
summary: Report highlights early effects of the pandemic on personal income; 'the tip of the iceberg'. Consumer spending, the U.S. economy's key driver, posted its steepest monthly decline in records tracing back to 1959 as much economic activity ceased amid the coronavirus pandemic.

title: All Tara Reade's Deniers
summary: The Democrats who attacked Brett Kavanaugh duck and cover for Joe Biden.. Joe Biden held a Virtual Women's Town Hall on Tuesday, and the minor news was Hillary Clinton's appearance and endorsement. The real news is what didn't happen. This was another public forum where Mr. Biden didn't address, and wasn't asked about, Tara Reade's allegation that he sexually assaulted her in 1993.

title: Why Parents Are Dressing Their Kids Like Budding Sneakerheads
summary: Moms and dads are decking out their young children in rare Nikes and Instagram-ready designer hoodies, but is it too much fashion, too soon?. ERIC CHENG STARTED collecting sneakers for his daughter before she was even born. The sneakers are a "reflection" of his own interest in sneakers, said Mr. Cheng, 36, a longtime collector who runs a creative marketing agency in Edmonton, Canada. Eight months ago, his daughter came home from the maternity ward with little Air Jordan 1 booties on her feet, despite the newborn's understandable ignorance of style. Mr. Cheng said he's always "trying to find the latest coolest stuff for her." Like father, like daughter.

title: De Blasio's 'Message' to Jews
summary: Other demographic groups get only sympathy when hit especially hard by the coronavirus pandemic.. New York

title: Unmasking the Vice President
summary: You may disapprove of the barefaced. But this is America.. Vice President Mike Pence invited a wave of media indignation this week when photos circulated of him touring the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., sans face mask. How could the guy in charge of the White House coronavirus task force be so cavalier? Doesn't he understand the message it sends?

title: What the ECB Did Thursday-and Why Investors Were Disappointed
summary: Banks lead broad decline in European stocks after ECB unveils new stimulus measures. Banks led a decline in European stocks Thursday after the European Central Bank wheeled out a complex basket of measures to help navigate the region's economy through a protracted recession brought on by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Twitter Posts Loss Despite User Growth
summary: San Francisco company reported its strongest user growth yet as a public company. Twitter Inc. on Thursday reported its strongest user growth yet as a public company but also swung to a loss for the first time in two years as advertisers tightened their budgets in response to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Lysol Maker Bets Cleaning Boom Will Outlast Coronavirus
summary: Hygiene companies boost production, launch new product to capitalize on greater demand. Consumers are cleaning their hands and homes more during the coronavirus pandemic, a trend makers of big hygiene brands are betting will outlast the Covid-19 crisis.

title: Kwame Anthony Appiah: Dreams Made Possible by Others
summary: Society depends on many small sacrifices that amount to a huge collective benefit.. At a normal commencement, there are two forms of celebration. On the one hand, we celebrate each graduate's individual achievements in getting a college degree. On the other, we applaud the families, the teachers and the classmates who sustained them. We recognize that there's something to honor in each of the students, while acknowledging, too, that they would not have made it on their own.

title: Has Trump Been Too Polite to Comey?
summary: A judge unseals documents showing the FBI's pursuit of a top Trump adviser.. There are still more troubling questions today about the historically aggressive use of investigative power by former FBI Director James Comey. The Journal's Aruna Viswanatha and Byron Tau report:

title: Federal Small-Business Aid: Too Little Bang, Too Few Bucks
summary: With over 30 million jobs lost, the U.S. government's spending on maintaining small-business employment hasn't been efficient. If the goal was to save as many jobs as possible, the places where the U.S. government's first $350 billion in small-business loans and grants went were less than ideal. Here's hoping the follow-on round of $310 billion in aid now under way is going better.

title: ECB Offers Cheap Loans to Banks to Stem Economic Downturn
summary: European Central Bank chief Lagarde says it is ready to expand bond buying, as it boosts firepower for coronavirus crisis. FRANKFURT-The European Central Bank rolled out its cheapest ever loans for eurozone banks and said it would consider expanding a €750 billion ($815 billion) bond-buying program, amplifying its firepower to contain the economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Good Enough Versus Even Better
summary: To find the best possible solution to a problem, scientists have to avoid the trap of the 'local maximum.'. If we could start from scratch, we'd be better off, no doubt, using metric units instead of inches and feet, duodecimal (base 12) numbers instead of decimals, and Dvorak keyboards instead of QWERTY. But in parts of the world where inches, decimals and QWERTY are the standard, people have built habits of thought and devices around them, so switching would be far from painless. These are homely examples of a profound issue that haunts both science and the human condition: the specter of local maxima.

title: Meat Companies Want to Reopen, but Officials Fear New Infections
summary: Agricultural officials say President Trump's executive order, following weeks of plant shutdowns, will safeguard American food security. President Trump's executive order allowing meatpacking plants to continue operating through the coronavirus pandemic is stirring concerns among local officials, wary of new spikes in infection rates if closed plants rush to reopen.

title: Joe Biden Names Advisers to Oversee Search for Running Mate
summary: The former vice president has said he will pick a woman for the role. WASHINGTON-Joe Biden has tapped a group of legal experts and political allies to oversee his search for a running mate, in his latest move to prepare for a potential future administration.

title: Carlyle Posts First-Quarter Loss
summary: Private-equity portfolio fell 8%, better than the 20% slide in broader markets. Carlyle Group Inc. reported a first-quarter loss, as the coronavirus pandemic hurt the value of its investments. However, the firm's private-equity portfolio proved more resilient than the broader market, and cash that could be returned to shareholders climbed from the previous year.

title: Chevron, BP, Shell Told to Cut Oil Output After Global Pact
summary: Oil-producing nations tell Western energy majors to curb production to help OPEC and G-20 effort to stabilize prices. The world's largest energy companies are negotiating production cuts with oil-rich nations ahead of Friday's deadline for OPEC and the Group of 20 countries to sharply reduce output-reductions that will limit these firms' options for coping with the crude-price rout.

title: BlackRock Names Sandra Boss New Corporate Watchdog
summary: She joins the money manager as it has tried to build a brand as an arbiter of corporate behavior. Money-management giant BlackRock Inc. installed a new executive to lead shareholder interactions with companies.

title: Older Vapers Are Turning Back to Cigarettes, Marlboro Maker Says
summary: Altria reports strong sales of tobacco products but says smokers will turn to cheaper cigarettes as downturn from coronavirus takes hold. Older smokers who had switched to e-cigarettes are turning back to traditional cigarettes because of negative news coverage and regulatory crackdowns on vaping, Marlboro maker Altria Group Inc. said Thursday.

title: How to Protect Your Credit if Your Income Takes a Hit
summary: If you take the right approach, lenders will often be willing to work out some relief. Amid job losses, reduced income and other economic hardships caused by the pandemic, taking steps to protect one's credit can be critical.

title: Japan Hands Cash to Households in $240 Billion Coronavirus Plan
summary: Government to give every person in country over$900; small businesses get cash and tax relief. TOKYO-Parliament passed a $240 billion spending plan that includes cash payments of over $900 to every person in Japan, following the U.S. in opening the public purse wide to address the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Macy's to Begin Reopening Stores on Monday
summary: The retailer will start with 68 stores in states that have loosened coronavirus restrictions; 'no-touch' beauty consultations. Macy's Inc. plans to reopen 68 stores on Monday in states that have loosened restrictions, joining a handful of other retailers that are limping back to life after the coronavirus forced them to shut stores.

title: A Real-Estate Developer Tried Decorating His Own Apartment. 'I Gave Up Right Away.'
summary: Michael Chetrit called in a professional interior designer when he realized how hard 'shopping' can be. Michael Chetrit has worked on many construction projects with interior designers during his 15-year tenure at The Chetrit Organization, a real-estate investment firm founded by his family. The 36-year-old Parisian native once believed that "all interior designers do is shop, and it's so easy, there's nothing to it." When he combined two apartments he owns in a Midtown building, he resolved to do the decorating himself.

title: McDonald's Sales Fall Amid Changing Dining Habits
summary: Burger chain sees disruptions lasting for months; 'getting back that breakfast business will be critical for us'. McDonald's Corp. said dramatic changes in consumer behavior during the coronavirus pandemic hurt its profit and sales, disruptions that the burger chain expects to continue for months.

title: Oxford University, AstraZeneca Join Forces for Coronavirus Vaccine
summary: Drug giant agrees to manufacture promising candidate if proved to work. AstraZeneca PLC has agreed to manufacture and distribute an experimental coronavirus vaccine from the University of Oxford-one of the most advanced candidates-in a partnership aimed at accelerating the widespread availability of the shot if it proves effective.

title: Please! Let Bill Belichick's Dog Coach the Patriots
summary: Stir craziness...or a logical next step in New England for an NFL draft night sensation?. Let the dog coach. Seriously. This September, or whenever the NFL starts-June 2037, five-game season, inside a sanitized bio-bubble aboard Jerry Jones's superyacht-I want Bill Belichick's dog paw-patrolling the New England Patriots sideline. I want the dog in a headset and hoodie. I want the dog barking gruff answers to mundane postgame questions.

title: Biden Aims to Make Up Ground With Latinos
summary: Many Democrats urge candidate to copy Bernie Sanders's outreach to young people while not isolating older generation. Joe Biden, seeking to unify the Democratic Party and generate voter enthusiasm in November's presidential election, is trying to make rapid inroads with Latinos, many of whom sided with Bernie Sanders in early primaries.

title: Virus Pushes Colleges to the Breaking Point, Forcing 'Hard Choices' About Education
summary: Resume Subscription. MacMurray College survived the Civil War, the Great Depression and two world wars, but not the coronavirus pandemic. The private liberal-arts school in central Illinois announced recently it will shut its doors for good in May, after 174 years.

title: Mexico's Economy Shrinks as Coronavirus Takes Toll
summary: GDP drops 1.6% in first quarter, but bigger hit is expected in second quarter. MEXICO CITY-Mexico's economy posted a sharp contraction in the first quarter, with industrial output and services falling from the previous quarter as the country felt the first economic effects of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Forget the Sourdough. Everybody's Baking Banana Bread.
summary: Homebound bakers salvage browning bananas left abandoned since the days of lockdown panic-buying. Vickie Jones normally isn't a fan of bananas. Even so, she grabbed a bunch while stocking up for an extended coronavirus lockdown at home in Harlingen, Texas.

title: China's Exporters Are Feeling Gloomy Even as Economy Restarts
summary: Factories are resuming production, but pandemic-triggered recessions around the world threaten to crater export demand. China's factories are resuming production, but pandemic-triggered recessions around the world have manufacturers pessimistic about export demand, figures published Thursday show.

title: Shell's Dividend Cut Is Harsh but Fair
summary: Oil major's decision is a sensible long-term move in a crisis of uncertainty for the industry. Shell is thinking long term. Its shareholders will need to do the same.

title: Twitter Could Lose Advertising Tug-of-War
summary: Twitter's results calmed anxious investors, but it is poorly-positioned relative to other social media peers as advertising shrinks. Investors shouldn't believe everything they read on social media or, for that matter, about social media.

title: Amy Chua: Hang In There, Graduates-and Don't Make Excuses
summary: Remember how lucky you are, keep trying hard things and work in a spirit of generosity. Class of 2020, my heart goes out to you! You've somehow made it through all those grueling tests and papers and messy breakups that always happen at the exact same time. You should be out partying, hugging your friends goodbye and excitedly awaiting the descent onto your sunny campus of all the relatives who love you and are so proud of you but can't necessarily stand each other and might actually want to claw each other's eyes out. But instead you're in quarantine, stuck in a house, possibly with those same people.

title: Kellogg Boosted by Higher Packaged-Food Spending
summary: Consumers shopping for packaged foods during the coronavirus pandemic drove organic net sales. Kellogg Co. on Thursday said consumers shopping for packaged foods during the coronavirus pandemic helped drive a key sales metric higher during the first quarter.

title: Coronavirus Causes Small Doctors' Offices to Scramble to Stay Afloat
summary: Practices across the country delay bills and seek funding to retain staff; asking patients to keep their appointments. Electrical cords snake across the lawn from Marc Price's small Malta, N.Y., family medical practice to a tent outside, where he examines patients suspected of having Covid-19. Unfortunately, isolating the impact of coronavirus on the finances of his practice isn't as simple: When not at his outpost, the doctor calls patients who have canceled appointments, hoping he can convince them to reconsider.

title: Lysol Maker Is Cleaning Up, but at What Cost?
summary: Reckitt Benckiser increased sales of its disinfectants and other products by 13% in the first quarter, but manufacturing expenses are also likely up. Reckitt Benckiser 's portfolio of household and health brands could have been designed for a pandemic. Keeping up with surging demand for products such as Lysol and Harpic cleaning fluid will be expensive, however.

title: WeWork Troubles Take Deeper Bite Out of SoftBank
summary: Japanese tech investor now expects $8.4 billion loss for recently ended fiscal year after it backed loans for shared-office company. TOKYO- SoftBank Group Corp. said steeper-than-expected losses on office-share firm WeWork pushed its expected net loss for the latest fiscal year to around ¥900 billion ($8.4 billion)-$1.4 billion more than it announced just two weeks ago.

title: Coronavirus Soars in Federal Prison Inmates
summary: Prisons officials expect the number of positive results to climb as testing is expanded. More than two thirds of the small number of federal prisoners who have been tested for the new coronavirus had positive results, top Bureau of Prisons officials said Wednesday, suggesting the outbreak behind bars may be more widespread than previously known.

title: Small Oil Drillers Are Turning Off Taps More Quickly Than Anticipated
summary: From Texas and Wyoming to North Dakota, smaller companies are concluding it is better to keep oil in the ground after prices crashed. Small U.S. oil companies are shutting off wells faster than expected, as prices fall below what it costs them to pump the crude out of the ground.

title: Workers Likely to Fare Better in Nations With Coronavirus Job-Retention Programs
summary: German and Japanese unemployment rates forecast to remain low, while U.S. rate jumps, but longer-term outlook is less clear. WASHINGTON-Workers in Germany and Japan are likely to weather an expected coronavirus-induced global recession better than their U.S. peers, thanks in part to stronger job-retention programs, recent data suggest.

title: Shell Cuts Dividend for First Time Since World War II
summary: Anglo-Dutch energy giant's net profit falls 48% from a year earlier after demand, prices plummet. LONDON- Royal Dutch Shell PLC cut its dividend for the first time since World War II as a steep drop in oil demand upends what has long been a fundamental bargain between oil majors and their investors.

title: Bring on the Gatsby Suit
summary: Head-to-toe pink in men's fashion? It's happening, old sport. From suiting to caps to shades, four ways men's fashion is embracing pink this summer. A pink thinking cap is the right idea. Hermès cap, $390, Hermès stores nationwide

title: With Author Brit Bennett's Second Novel, a Literary Star Is Born
summary: In 'The Vanishing Half,' her follow-up to 2016's breakthrough novel 'The Mothers,' the 29-year-old novelist expresses an unlikely affinity: "I just love a severe older woman.". Brit Bennett likes women with an edge. "I just like mean women," the 29-year-old novelist says, referring to the stern characters she meets both in person and in her own writing. "My mom was not that type of maternal figure at all, so I really have no idea where to trace that connection in my own personal life-but I just love a severe older woman."

title: Stock Market Surge Isn't as Crazy as It Seems
summary: Those who think the market is missing something because it is up so much are misinterpreting what has driven it to those levels. The disconnect between the stock market message of glad tidings to capitalists and the economy's slump into the worst performance since the Great Depression is unmissable. Are investors making a horrible mistake?

title: Kraft Heinz Reports Higher Demand for Staples
summary: Food maker's U.S. sales increased 6.4% to about $4.5 billion. Kraft Heinz Co. reported higher demand for many of its products in the first quarter as consumers in the U.S. snapped up food to eat at home during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Coronavirus Relief: What Borrowers Should Know About Skipping Jumbo Payments
summary: Many lenders are allowing homeowners to put a hold on payments, but borrowers should know the terms. Jumbo-loan borrowers may feel like the forgotten stepchildren of the pandemic: They are not mentioned in the recently passed Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (Cares) Act, which guarantees 180 days of forbearance to borrowers in government-backed loans. They were also not addressed in an April 27 announcement by the Federal Housing Finance Agency that borrowers aren't required to make lump-sum payments after a forbearance period.

title: Tech Entrepreneurs Form Coalition to Help Source Coronavirus Supplies
summary: Initiative is part of a broader private-sector response to pandemic to help with masks, gowns and other equipment in short supply. A pair of tech entrepreneurs has started a coalition including companies and nonprofits to help address a shortage of medical supplies for health-care workers fighting the coronavirus pandemic, an effort that has grown to include companies from Volkswagen AG to health-care distributor Cardinal Health Inc.

title: Microsoft Offers Some Shelter From the Storm
summary: The software giant's business diversity proves an advantage in the pandemic-driven slump. Will Microsoft prove to be resilient in the global pandemic and its aftermath? The answer suggested by the software titan's latest results is: Yes-but it's complicated.

title: Trump's Trade Deal With China Is Another Coronavirus Victim
summary: The pandemic is exposing the perils of agreements based on numerical targets rather than tariff reductions or policy concessions. Covid-19 has disrupted trade flows and economies all over the world. No surprise, then, that it is disrupting hopes for better trade relations between the U.S. and China, too.

title: Aurora Capital Targets $1.8 Billion for Sixth Flagship Fund
summary: The midmarket firm has collected $1.6 billion so far for its latest buyout fund despite coronavirus pandemic challenges. Midmarket-focused Aurora Capital Partners has surpassed its original target for its sixth flagship private-equity fund but isn't done raising capital yet, people familiar with the matter said.

title: Tesla: Too Fast, Too Furious
summary: Pleasing first-quarter results do little to justify the auto maker's recent rally or stratospheric valuation in the coronavirus crisis. Wall Street keeps betting that Tesla and Elon Musk can keep defying financial gravity. Its latest results will stoke that confidence for now.

title: With the World Distracted by Coronavirus, Hopes for Peace in Ukraine Are Dimming
summary: Resume Subscription. MARIUPOL, Ukraine-The sound of gunfire and shelling has become a staple of everyday life here in this city in eastern Ukraine, where hopes for an end to the long-running war between Russian-backed separatists and Kyiv have faded since this winter's tentative detente between Russian President Vladimir Putin and his Ukrainian counterpart, Volodymyr Zelensky.

title: Saudi Arabia Set Its Sights on English Soccer. The Premier League Wasn't Prepared.
summary: Newcastle United didn't fit the typical profile for Saudi investment. But with the takeover, it's set to inherit all of the kingdom's controversies.. In the two decades since English soccer threw its doors open to billions of dollars of overseas investment, the private acquisition of a middling team has seldom become a matter of human rights, geopolitics or international piracy.

title: Ginkgo Bioworks Redirects Its Biotech Platform to Coronavirus
summary: Startup valued at around $4.2 billion shifts resources to pandemic fight. Ginkgo Bioworks Inc. has raised $719 million since it launched in 2008 to develop biotechnology solutions for industries as varied as cosmetics, agriculture and pharmaceuticals.

title: Disney+ in a Programming Crunch Due to Coronavirus Shutdown
summary: Disney's streaming service has subscribers but a less-robust library compared with Netflix, other rivals. ﻿LOS ANGELES-The shutdown of Hollywood is disrupting the Disney+ pipeline.

title: Coronavirus Tracking Apps Raise Questions About Bluetooth Security
summary: Hackers might seek to exploit devices if more people have Bluetooth permanently switched on; accuracy of Bluetooth location-tracking is limited. Governments and companies are planning to introduce mobile applications that use Bluetooth to track coronavirus infections. Researchers say the technology keeps users' identifying data private, but the complexity of working with Bluetooth raises cybersecurity concerns.

title: How to IPO During Coronavirus: This Executive Helps From His Kitchen Counter
summary: Nasdaq's Jay Heller works on getting companies to go public, a process gone remote during the pandemic without in-person roadshows or bell-ringing ceremonies; 'my commute is a lot better'. Jay Heller, the Nasdaq Inc. executive who helps companies go public, is usually surrounded by hundreds of celebrating bankers, employees and their family members in the middle of Times Square when a firm starts trading.

title: Liquidity Crisis or Solvency Crisis? It Matters to Fed
summary: If central bank is too concerned about getting its money back, it may shun weaker companies. Is the economy facing a liquidity crisis, or a solvency crisis? The distinction will determine how important the Federal Reserve is to returning the economy to health.

title: Société Générale Posts Surprise Loss as Bad-Loan Charges Surge
summary: French bank to cut costs by up to a further $760 million this year. French bank Société Générale SA said it would cut costs and rework its strategy after bad-loan charges tripled in the first quarter and stock-trading revenue was wiped out by disruption from the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Elon Musk: 'Give People Back Their Goddamn Freedom'
summary: Tesla CEO rails against coronavirus-caused closure of auto maker's lone U.S. assembly plant after reporting surprise first-quarter profit. Tesla Inc. reported a surprise first-quarter profit Wednesday while Chief Executive Elon Musk highlighted uncertainty and risk ahead, citing the forced shutdown of businesses including its lone U.S. assembly plant-a government action he equated with fascism.

title: PG&E Ordered by Judge to Overhaul Tree Trimming
summary: Company criticized for failing to maintain electric grid even as it paid shareholder dividends. A federal judge is ordering PG&E Corp. to overhaul its tree-trimming and power line inspection practices after the company pleaded guilty to state manslaughter charges for sparking the deadliest wildfire in California history.

title: The Government Economy
summary: GDP shrinks 4.8% as private spending and investment plunge.. State and federal governments are now essentially running the American economy. How do you like it? That's the biggest news in Wednesday's initial estimate for first quarter economic growth, which shrank at a 4.8% annual rate. Governments shut down private commerce in March, and the private investment and consumption that drive American prosperity fell off a cliff.

title: Venezuela Proposes Major Overhaul of Energy Sector
summary: Plan looks to downsize national oil monopoly while ambitiously aiming to double production. Venezuela's government is proposing a sweeping overhaul of its energy industry, scaling back the role of the state and handing over greater control to private companies in an effort to boost plummeting oil output, according to a government presentation.

title: Trump Administration Remains Hopeful on China Trade Pact as Doubts Grow
summary: Senior U.S. trade official expressed confidence that Beijing will meet obligations under deal with Washington. WASHINGTON-A senior U.S. trade official expressed confidence Wednesday that Beijing will meet its obligations under the trade deal with Washington, despite fallout from the coronavirus pandemic and doubts by experts about China's ability to meet purchase targets.

title: Trump Says He's Ready to Hit the Road to Arizona, Coronavirus or Not
summary: President hasn't been shy about his hunger to get back on the road-and to convene rallies. WASHINGTON-President Trump, like much of the nation, has cabin fever. That's about to end.

title: Fed's Powell Says More Spending Will Be Needed From Congress
summary: Federal Reserve warns that public health crisis "will weigh heavily on economic activity". WASHINGTON-Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell delivered an uncharacteristically blunt call on Wednesday for Congress and the White House to spend more money to prevent deeper economic damage from the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Joe Grogan to Resign as Top White House Domestic Policy Adviser
summary: The head of the president's Domestic Policy Council has played a key role in the coronavirus response. WASHINGTON-Top White House policy adviser Joe Grogan is leaving his post, the latest sign of turnover as the administration grapples with a coronavirus pandemic.
